name: action queue
description:
Even though the game saves multiple inputs each input is tried to be executed once, if this doesnt work the command is removed from the queue anyway.
dota

name: apply preknown language
description: players must use their knowledge of a language (learned outside of the game) to solve problems

name: apply rules
description:
games rules (or rules of logic) are used to solve problems

merged tags: deduction, rules

name: automation
description: Automating processes via game mechanics is helpful or mandatory for problem solving

name: blueprint
description: players can define or build blueprints that function as a planning help

name: body language
description: body language is a central topic, e.g. when players must analyze body language to make a decision

name: building and crafting
description: problems are solved by building and crafting, e.g. building farms that produce required goods or crafting items to kill enemies more easily

name: busywork
description:
problems are solved by completing tasks that are often trivial or take a long time to complete

previously ...
players must simply do work in order to progress, but the work does not require problem solving as such

name: com: chat wheel
description:
players can post premade messages to a chat, usually by using a wheel where they can choose between a set of available messages

This acts as a barrier for toxicity and does not require devs to implement chat filters.

name: com: external
description: players use their (spatial) proximity to each other to communicate without using any game features for that purpose

name: com: free drawing
description: players can draw to communicate with other players, e.g. by drawing on a map to indicate where something is

name: com: free gestures
description: This might be part of VR games.

name: com: npc and npc
description: NPCs talk to each other (e.g. ambient dialog or cutscenes) which can act as a source of information for the player

name: com: npc and player
description: NPCs communicate with the player (not their in-game character), e.g. in a tutorial

name: com: npc and playercharacter
description: players can communicate with NPCs via their in-game character, e.g. to gather information, complete quests, trade resources or just chat

name: com: proximity communication
description: communication is bound to a location, e.g. players can only hear each other when they are close to each other in the game world

name: communication
description: players must communicate to coordinate their game actions or solve problems

name: contradiction
description: players must find contradictions

name: copypaste
description: predefined, self created, global, lokal, clipboard

name: detective work
description: e.g. whodunit

name: direct
description:
dota
die reihenfolge ist direkt abhängig vom spieler input. Aktionen die zuerst eingegeben werden werden zuerst ausgeführt.

name: direction display
description: players are automatically guided to a location, e.g. via markers or a trail

name: discover or learn rules
description: players must use inductive reasoning to solve problems

name: exploit as blueprint
description: Players can define areas where something should happen

name: exploration
description:
player investigates an area in the hopes of finding something new that helps with game progress, e.g. find items or new NPCs to talk to

game progress is required for changes to an already explored area

name: game of skill or dexterity
description:
the game requires players to have mastered a skill (usally hand-eye coordination) to a certain degree

this does not include all games where the player needs to click on things

name: gameobject personalization
description: cosmetics, object coloring, renaming

name: gather information
description: players must identify and gather information themselves to progress, e.g. by inspecting objects or talking to NPCs

name: ginfo: dialog
description: players often progress by choosing an (appropriate) dialog option

name: ginfo: predefined notes
description:
merge tags:
predefined notes, premade notes

name: grinding
description:
very similar to busywork: players continuously do the same activity, e.g. kill a specific enemy type.

Can be motivated internally (players want to level-up) or because the game difficulty forces them to by not providing other means of progressing.

name: indirect
description:
spiel organisiert verteilung/abarbeitung der aufgaben selbst
z.b. prison architect

Der spieler hat nur indirekten einfluss auf die reihenfolge

name: info: connect
description: players can (visually) connect pieces of information, e.g. via red strings like a graph

name: info: hide
description:
players can (visually) hide information not relevant to the current problem, e.g. by clicking an item to reduce its rendering opacity

this does not include being able to show or hide information in windows, e.g. a quest log

name: info: highlight
description: players can (visually) highlight specific information that they deem relevant, e.g. an item or piece of text

name: info: record
description: players can record information themselves, e.g. by a text note

name: info: tag
description: players can tag information, which can be abstract or concrete, e.g. by tagging video clips based on their content

name: ingame pathtrail
description: directions are given via a path that is overlayed on the map, e.g. to show players which way they must go

name: inputbuffer
description:
Input is persistent even if it can not be executed immediately.

the game might try to do it multiple times or forever until the action succeeds

z.b. sims, prison architekt

name: language
description: language is a central topic for problem solving

name: learn programming
description: players must learn a programming language (fictional or real) to solve problems provided by the game

name: learn unknown language
description: players must learn an unkownn (real of fictitious) language (for people) that they use to solve problems

name: leave behind artifacts
description: Multiplayer

name: logic challenges
description:
merge tags:
riddles, logic puzzles

name: map drawing
description: players can draw on a map

name: mini: busywork
description: minigames that consist of busywork (see "busywork" tag), e.g. trivial and repetitive tasks

name: mini: logic
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved by employing logic, e.g Towers of Hanoi

name: mini: skill
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved through skill, e.g clicking objects in a short time frame in the correct order

name: minigames
description: includes mini-games that reward players with progress in some form

name: misleading choices
description: players may think they have different possibilities but will end up in the same position regardless

name: mng: consumables
description: alles was verbrauchbar ist, geld, resourcen, essbares

name: mng: skills and items
description: items gleichbedeutend mit equipment, included cooldowns, auswahl von items

name: organization
description: players must organize resources to succeed (e.g min-maxing)

name: parallel
description:
mehrere befehle werden in einem moment ausgeführt. der spieler kann zum beispiel pausieren, eine aktion für verschiedene units auswählen, die dann gleichzeitig ausgeführt werden.
z.b. mass effect

name: personalization
description: players can customize objects in the game, e.g. by renaming, coloring or more

name: pew pew
description: players must overcome enemies with violence to progress

name: physics
description: problem solving involves systems and rules based on physics, e.g. jump-and-run or more complex puzzles

name: placeable symbols
description: players can add location markers (e.g. to a map)

name: point and click
description: the game belongs to the point-and-click genre, i.e. players must solve riddles by talking to NPCs, combining and using items

name: possibilities
description: players can define which possibilities they think are relevant

name: practicing
description: Even if i already can do something i might want to get better at it.

name: predefined symbols
description: players can see markers or symbols that provide information

name: puzzle pieces
description: players need to assemble pieces in the correct manner, e.g. when presenting evidence

name: queuegame
description: e.g. Dorfromantik

name: random components
description: players face challenges that include random components, e.g. random maps, tools, cards or enemies

name: realtime
description:
Der spieler kann zwar inputs speichern hat aber nachträglich keinen einfluss auf die queue

Slay the Spire (uneditierbare Echtzeit-Queue)

name: recipe
description: players can use recipes to solve proplems, e.g. crafting items

name: red herings
description: story bait

name: resource management
description:
merge tags:
strategy (optional), strategy, organization of game resources

name: scouting
description: player wants to (repeadetly) investigate an area, e.g. to check that nothing is there or to get information on an enemy

name: secrets
description: game content that is hidden or not easily accessible, e.g. easter eggs, treasures, special endings ..

name: sequential
description: einträge der queue werden der reihe nach abgearbeitet

name: skilltree
description: character editor

name: social deduction
description: players need to engage in social deduction

name: strategic planning
description: players must devise an appropriate strategy to solve problems

name: strategy problem
description: game problems are of a strategic nature, e.g. players must manage resources and make plans to overcome challenges

name: template
description: players can define blueprints or template to reuse at another point in time

name: text in world
description: players can add (persistent) text to the game world

name: text search
description: players can search through information by specifying search terms

name: top: time
description: This tag marks games that have time as a central topic. For example when the needs to achieve something in a specific amount of time, or when a groundhog day scenario is at play.

name: trial and error
description: players solve problems via trial and error since they can just try out different solution strategies without penalty (or with reloading)

name: ui personalization
description: players can personalize some parts of the UI to better match their preferences

name: ui: sandbox
description: players can freely personalize the UI, e.g. by moving windows (rollercoaster, banished) or by changing the layout (DotA 2)

name: ui: settings
description: players can personalize UI settings to some extent, e.g. color blind mode and hotkey bindings

name: vio: enact
description: enact violence like killing creatures and defeating enemies

name: vio: experience
description:
Experience violence. For example as a victim or as a witness. Even games where the player is peaceful can be tag with this.

Example:
Valiant Hearts: The Great War

name: auto: assemble
description: An automation should be something that could also be done manually OR an essential part of the game. Therefore replacing manual labor while preferably introducing a certain depth.

name: auto: configure
description: An automation should be something that could also be done manually OR an essential part of the game. Therefore replacing manual labor while preferably introducing a certain depth.

name: automation
description: Automating processes via game mechanics is helpful or mandatory for problem solving

description:
players can post premade messages to a chat, usually by using a wheel where they can choose between a set of available messages

This acts as a barrier for toxicity and does not require devs to implement chat filters.

name: com: external
description: players use their (spatial) proximity to each other to communicate without using any game features for that purpose

name: com: free drawing
description: players can draw to communicate with other players, e.g. by drawing on a map to indicate where something is

name: com: free gestures
description: This might be part of VR games.

description: NPCs talk to each other (e.g. ambient dialog or cutscenes) which can act as a source of information for the player

name: com: npc and player
description: NPCs communicate with the player (not their in-game character), e.g. in a tutorial. This can include narrators.

name: com: npc and playercharacter
description: players can communicate with NPCs via their in-game character, e.g. to gather information, complete quests, trade resources or just chat

name: com: proximity communication
description:
communication is bound to a location, e.g. players can only hear each other when they are close to each other in the game world.
This is allowed to be tagged for single player games.

name: enact violence
description: players solve problems or progress by enacting violence like killing creatures and defeating enemies

description: cosmetics, object coloring, renaming

name: gather information
description: players must identify and gather information themselves to progress, e.g. by inspecting objects or talking to NPCs

name: ginfo: dialog
description: players often progress by choosing an (appropriate) dialog option

name: ginfo: exploration
description:
player investigates an area in the hopes of finding something new that helps with game progress, e.g. find items or new NPCs to talk to

game progress is required for changes to an already explored area

predefined notes, premade notes

name: ginfo: scouting
description: player wants to (repeadetly) investigate an area, e.g. to check that nothing is there or to get information on an enemy

name: ginfo: text search
description: players can search through information by specifying search terms

name: goc: critical failure
description: e.g. death, resets to a previous point in the game, thereby losing any progress between this point and the critical failure

name: info: connect
description: players can (visually) connect pieces of information, e.g. via red strings like a graph

name: info: mark/tag
description: players can tag information, which can be abstract or concrete, e.g. by tagging video clips based on their content

name: info: other
description: placeholder for any missing tags, e.g. arranging information

name: info: record
description: players can record information themselves, e.g. by a text note

name: info: show/hide
description:
players can (visually) hide information not relevant to the current problem, e.g. by clicking an item to reduce its rendering opacity

this does not include being able to show or hide information in windows, e.g. a quest log

name: information
description: players must organize resources to succeed (e.g min-maxing)

name: int: highlight
description: players can (visually) highlight specific information that they deem relevant, e.g. an item or piece of text

name: int: visual aid
description: the game has visual aids like painting ledges that can be climbed on in a particular color

name: leave behind artifacts
description: Multiplayer

name: map: drawing
description: players can draw on a map

name: map: path trail
description: path trails are shown on a map

name: map: place symbols
description: players can add symbols to a map, e.g. location markers

name: map: quicktravel
description: players can use a map to quickly travel to other locations. OBACHT: A game feature is only quicktravel, if the player could also travel the same distance a slower way e.g. walking by foot vs clicking on the minimap.

name: map: symbols
description: players can see markers or symbols that provide information on a map

name: mechanics
description: A mechanic is a feature that the game provides such that the player is able to accomplish game given tasks. This is not the same as what you do.

name: mechanics: ai companion
description: does not include escort missions

name: mechanics: challenges
description: Quests (optional)/Grants

name: mechanics: change game speed
description: slow motion, bullettime, pause, speedup, and so on

name: mechanics: other
description: for any missing tags related to mechanics

name: mechanics: quest tracker display
description: players can see their current quest objectives/tasks displayed on the screen (automatically or by setting a quest as active)

name: mechanics: vision
description: something is visible, you or others

name: mini: busywork
description: minigames that consist of busywork (see "busywork" tag), e.g. trivial and repetitive tasks

name: mini: logic
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved by employing logic, e.g Towers of Hanoi

name: mini: skill
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved through skill, e.g clicking objects in a short time frame in the correct order

name: minigames
description: includes mini-games that reward players with progress in some form

name: misc: secrets
description: game content that is hidden or not easily accessible, e.g. easter eggs, treasures, special endings ..

name: misc: skilltree & upgrades
description: game includes a skill or research tree where abilities are successively unlocked

name: mng: compose team
description: compose team requires units need to influence each other e.g. in terms of interaction (Seiteneffekte, Wechselwirkungen)

name: mng: consumables
description: players need to manage consumable resources like money, materials, potions, etc.

name: mng: inventory
description: inventory limited by space or weight, choose which items to keep

name: mng: items
description:
Manage which items are used e.g. selecting from a set or collection.
Choose item for a slot.
items gleichbedeutend mit equipment

name: mng: skills
description:
includes cooldowns
when you use it 
when you upgrade it

name: mul: local coop
description: TODO rename to LAN local area network

name: organize information
description:
players must organize resources to succeed (e.g min-maxing)
the organization tree does contain elements in which the player organizes information in some way

name: pc: logic challenges
description:
merge tags:
riddles, logic puzzles

name: pc: skill or dexterity
description:
the game requires players to have mastered a skill (usally hand-eye coordination) to a certain degree

this does not include all games where the player needs to click on things

name: pc: strategy challenges
description: game problems are of a strategic nature, e.g. players must manage resources and make plans to overcome challenges

name: personalization
description: players can customize objects in the game, e.g. by renaming, coloring or more

name: rep: gameplay branches
description:
the game provides mechanics that result in different ways of playing the game (e.g. skilltree)

this does not apply to scenarios where the core gameplay is the same but with a slightly different flavor (e.g. pokemon)

name: rep: meta progression
description: players progress after finishing a game/match (e.g. increasing a character level in multiplayer games, etc.)

name: rep: narrative branches
description:
players can use different game mechanics (skills, weapons, items) or resource strategies to complete the game

merge tags:
narrative choices, narrative branches

name: rep: scoring system
description: game includes a scoring or ranking system that may motivate players to replay (sections of) the game

name: rep: unlock content
description: players unlock new content after finishing the game or a run of the game, e.g. new levels, new cosmetics, new game modes, story elements

name: res: apply logic
description:
merge tags:
apply abstract rules, discover or learn rules

name: res: apply physics
description: problem solving involves systems and rules based on physics, e.g. jump-and-run or more complex puzzles

name: res: combine information
description: players need to assemble pieces in the correct manner, e.g. when presenting evidence

name: res: learn or apply language
description:
merge tags:
apply preknown language, body language, learn programming, learn unknown language

name: res: social deduction
description: players need to engage in social deduction

name: res: strategic planning
description: players must devise an appropriate strategy to solve problems

name: resource management
description:
merge tags:
strategy (optional), strategy, organization of game resources

name: rpt: grinding
description:
very similar to busywork: players continuously do the same activity, e.g. kill a specific enemy type.

Can be motivated internally (players want to level-up) or because the game difficulty forces them to by not providing other means of progressing.

name: rpt: practicing
description: Even if i already can do something i might want to get better at it.

name: rpt: trial and error
description: players solve problems via trial and error since they can just try out different solution strategies without penalty (or with reloading)

name: sch: blueprint
description: players can define or build blueprints that function as a planning help

name: sch: copypaste
description: predefined, self created, global, lokal, clipboard

name: sch: recipe
description: players can use recipes to solve proplems, e.g. crafting items

name: sch: template
description: players can define blueprints or template to reuse at another point in time

name: schemata
description: problems are solved by building and crafting, e.g. building farms that produce required goods or crafting items to kill enemies more easily

name: settings
description: the place or type of surroundings where something is positioned or where an event takes place

name: spn: object quicktravel
description: players can quicktravel by using objects in the game world, like portals, teleport scrolls, gates, etc.

name: text in world
description: players can add (persistent) text to the game world

name: top: other
description: for any missing topics, e.g. technology

name: top: time
description: This tag marks games that have time as a central topic. For example when the needs to achieve something in a specific amount of time, or when a groundhog day scenario is at play.

name: ui personalization
description: players can personalize some parts of the UI to better match their preferences

name: ui: accessibility
description: players can personalize UI settings to some extent, e.g. color blind mode and hotkey bindings

name: ui: sandbox
description: players can freely personalize the UI, e.g. by moving windows (rollercoaster, banished) or by changing the layout (DotA 2)

name: vis: icons & symbols
description: icons or symbols that encode game-relevant data (cannot be JUST ui elements)

name: vis: other
description: vis collection tag

name: wyd: detective work
description: e.g. whodunit

name: ai companions
description:
the game includes AI companions that accompany the player (if there is a player character) for some time

NOTICE: does not include escort missions

name: ai: commandable
description: AI companions can be commanded (fully or partially)

name: ai: uncommandable
description: AI companions cannot be commanded

name: auto: assemble
description:
automation is directly build/assembled, usually some kind of machine

something can only count as automation if it could also be done manually by the player in some other way, with the automation therefore replacing manual labor (preferably introducing a certain depth)

name: auto: configure
description:
automation is configured but not directly build/assembled

something can only count as automation if it could also be done manually by the player in some other way, with the automation therefore replacing manual labor (preferably introducing a certain depth)

name: automation
description: automating processes via game mechanics is helpful or mandatory for problem solving

name: character editor
description: the game has a character editor which allows the player to personalize the character they play to some degree (age, gender, name, class, race, ..)

name: chunk: continuous
description: no clear boundaries, seamless transitions between different game parts

name: chunk: package wise
description: clear boundaries, different game parts can be named (or even separately chosen to play again)

name: chunkiness
description: how game contents are packaged, i.e. are there no clear boundaries between different game parts (open world) or are there clear separations (levels)

name: com: chat wheel
description:
players can post premade messages to a chat, usually by using a wheel where they can choose between a set of available messages

This acts as a barrier for toxicity and does not require devs to implement chat filters.

name: com: external
description: players communicate outside of the game, e.g. because they are in the same location or by using other software

name: com: free drawing
description: players can draw to communicate with other players, e.g. by drawing on a map to indicate where something is

name: com: free gestures
description: players can communicate via free gestures (most likely only VR games)

name: com: gestures
description: players can communicate using a set of predefined gestures their character can make

name: com: markers and pings
description: players can communicate through markers and pings, i.e., small symbolic representations

name: com: npc and npc
description: NPCs talk to each other (e.g. ambient dialog or cutscenes) which can act as a source of information for the player

name: com: npc and player
description: NPCs communicate with the player (not their in-game character), e.g. in a tutorial. This can include narrators.

name: com: npc and playercharacter
description: players can communicate with NPCs via their in-game character, e.g. to gather information, complete quests, trade resources or just chat

name: com: proximity communication
description:
Communication is bound to a location, e.g. players can only hear each other when they are close to each other in the game world.
This is allowed to be tagged for single player games.

name: com: soundboard
description: players can communicate through a sound board, e.g., through a set of predefined spoken lines (voiced by someone else)

name: com: text chat
description: players can communicate through a text chat

name: com: voice chat
description: players can communicate through a voice chat

name: communication
description: how communication is handled in the game

name: content & substance
description: the general content and substance of a game in terms of topics and setting

name: dd: arrow indicator
description: players are shown a direction through an arrow indicator

name: dd: compass
description: players can understand directions through a compass

name: dd: ingame path trail
description: directions are given through a path that is overlayed on the game world, e.g. to show players which way they must go

name: direction display
description: the game provides directional displays for spatial guidance

name: enact violence
description: players solve problems or progress by enacting violence like killing creatures and defeating enemies

name: exp: heterogeneous
description: players get a diverse game experience

name: exp: homogeneous
description: players get a more homogeneous game experience

name: form
description: the form of a game, including its mechanics and structure

name: free communication
description: communcation with some degree of free expression

name: game experience
description: how diverse the game experience is, i.e., are there many different aspects and activities to it or is it largely the same

name: game object personalization
description: players can personalize game objects, e.g., through naming, coloring or cosmetics (clothing, hair styles)

name: game over condition
description: how/when the game is over

name: gather information
description: players must identify and gather information themselves to progress, e.g. by inspecting objects or talking to NPCs

name: genre
description: which genre from other media (film, literature) the game can be assigned to

name: ginfo: dialog
description: players collect information by talking to NPCs

name: ginfo: exploration
description: players gather information by investigating their environment in the hopes of finding something, e.g. new items, an NPCs to talk to, etc.

name: ginfo: lookup
description:
players gather information by looking up information in the game (looking at letters, looking at the quest log)

NOTICE: this does not include *searching*

name: ginfo: remember self
description: players must take care to remember gathered information themselves, since the game does not track it

name: ginfo: scouting
description: player collect information by (repeadetly) investigating an area, e.g. to check that nothing is there or to get information on an enemy

name: ginfo: text search
description: players can search through information by specifying search terms

name: goc: critical failure
description: game is over when the player fails critically, e.g., death, resets to a previous point in the game, thereby losing any progress between this point and the critical failure

name: goc: none
description: there is no direct game over condition, e.g., because the game continues after the story ends (Minecraft) or because there was no end to begin with (endless mode)

name: goc: permadeath
description: when the player dies, the game resets to the start

name: goc: reach endpoint
description: the game ends when a certain point is reached, e.g., the conclusion of the main quest

name: info: arrange
description: players can spatially arrange information

name: info: connect
description: players can (visually) connect pieces of information, e.g. via red strings like a graph

name: info: distribute
description: players must distribute information amongst themselves to tackle problems (multiplayer only)

name: info: mark/tag
description: players can tag information, which can be abstract or concrete, e.g. by tagging video clips based on their content

name: info: other
description: placeholder for any missing tags to organize information

name: info: record
description: players can record information themselves, e.g. with a text note

name: info: visibility
description:
players can (visually) hide information not relevant to the current problem, e.g. by clicking an item to reduce its rendering opacity

this does not include being able to show or hide information in windows, e.g. a quest log

name: information
description: players must organize resources to succeed (e.g min-maxing)

name: int: highlight
description: visual highlights, e.g. for status changes, important entities, etc.

name: int: new data
description: the game communicates that new data is available to the player, e.g., a new quest, new log entry, new armor, etc.

name: int: visual aid
description: the game has visual aids (mostly for navigation) like ledges that are painted in a particular color to indicate that they can be climbed on

name: leave behind artifacts
description: players can leave behind artifacts in a shared game world

name: map: drawing
description: players can draw on a map

name: map: minimap
description: the game includes a minimap version of a larger map

name: map: path trail
description: path trails are shown on a map

name: map: place symbols
description: players can place symbols on the map, e.g. location markers

name: map: quicktravel
description:
players can use a map to quickly travel to other locations

NOTICE: A game feature is only quicktravel if the player could also travel the same distance in a slower way e.g. walking by foot vs clicking on the minimap.

name: map: symbols
description: the game includes a map (at all), usually with symbols that provide information on specific locations

name: mech: card game
description: Has mechanics based around card games. This can be actual card games or just prominent elements of card games.

name: mech: challenges
description: (optional) content intended to challenge players' skill

name: mech: change game speed
description: players can change the speed of the game, e.g., through slow motion/bullet time, by having a tactical pause or directly controling the speed (slower/faster)

name: mech: combos
description: the game has combos in some sense, e.g., when players successfully chain or combine (specific) attacks, when players can craft combos, etc.

name: mech: configurable quick access
description: player can configure some type of quick access

name: mech: other
description: for any missing tags related to mechanics

name: mech: physical save points
description:
there are physical objects in the game where the player can save and/or rest, optionally with replenishing their health

saving can mean creating a new save file or getting a new check point

name: mech: place & arrange
description: players can place and arrange objects inside the game world, usually employed for building

name: mech: predefined notes
description: the game provides information in the form of notes, audio diaries, encylopedias, letters, etc.

name: mech: quest tracker display
description: players can see their current quest objectives/tasks displayed on the screen (automatically or by setting a quest as active)

name: mech: queue
description: players can queue specific actions like movement or more complex commands; does not count if the game only internally uses a queue

name: mech: quicktime events
description: events that require players to press a specific button in a given amount of time; can have bad consequences if failed

name: mech: skilltree & upgrades
description: game includes a systems, like a skill or research tree, where upgrades are successively unlocked

name: mech: stealth
description: the game has stealth mechanics like sneaking, wearing disguises or stealing

name: mech: transform
description: players can transform things inside the game into other things, e.g. crafting

name: mech: vehicles & mounts
description: players can use vehicles or mounts (e.g., horses, dragons, etc.) to traverse the world

name: mechanics
description: A mechanic is a feature that the game provides such that the player is able to accomplish game given tasks. This is not the same as what you do.

name: meta-mechanics
description: high-level features of a game

name: mini: busywork
description: minigames that consist of busywork (see "busywork" tag), e.g. trivial and repetitive tasks

name: mini: logic
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved by employing logic, e.g Towers of Hanoi

name: mini: skill
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved through skill, e.g clicking objects in a short time frame in the correct order

name: minigames
description: mini-games that reward players with progress in some form

name: misc
description: miscellaneous

name: misc: collectibles
description: the game has collectible items that players can collect during gameplay and that are usually displayed in a gallery somewhere

name: misc: community content
description: the game allows for community content (e.g., via the steam workshop)

name: misc: difficulty settings
description: the game allows players to customize the difficulty by selecting a difficulty level or customized game settings that influence difficulty

name: misc: educational
description:
the game includes educational content that directly aims to be educational

NOTICE: This does not include when information/architecture is based on the real-world but just part of the game as such. There must be obvious intent to educate.

name: misc: secrets
description: the game includes content that is hidden or not easily accessible, e.g. easter eggs, treasures, special endings ..

name: misc: tutorial
description: the game includes a tutorial of some kind (can be big or small)

name: mng: compose team
description:
players need to compose a team of units

requires that units influence each other e.g. in terms of interaction

name: mng: consumables
description: players need to manage consumable resources like money, materials, potions, etc.

name: mng: inventory
description: players need to manage their inventory , which is limited by space or weight (choose which items to keep)

name: mng: items
description: players need to manage which items they use, buy, equip, etc.

name: mng: skills
description: players need to manage skills, e.g., when to use a skill, when to upgrade it or which skills to equip

name: mng: time
description: players need to manage time, e.g., because the game has other systems based around time

name: mng: units
description: players need to manage mutliple units

name: mul: couch coop
description: cooperative multiplayer that is played in the same location, using a single device

name: mul: leave game objects
description: players can leave behind objects in the shared world

name: mul: leave text
description: players can add (persistent) text to the game world

name: mul: local multiplayer
description: multiplayer that is played in the same network (LAN), using multiple devices

name: mul: online multiplayer
description: multiplayer that is played online (using multiple devices)

name: multiplayer
description: multiplayer mechanics and categories

name: npc communication
description: which type of communication with NPCs is available

name: ord: branches
description: game contents can be experienced/accessed in a branched order, i.e., there are different options but still some restrictions

name: ord: linear
description: game contents can only be experienced/accessed in a predetermined linear order

name: ord: open
description: game contents can be experienced/accessed in any order, e.g., in open-world games

name: order
description: describes in which order game contents can be experienced/accessed

name: organize information
description: players can organize information to progress (or make their lives easier)

name: pc: discovery
description: challenge based on discovery of new information about the story, game world, characters, etc.

name: pc: emotional challenges
description: challenge based on emotional reactions to story developments or other parts of the game

name: pc: labor or busywork
description: challenge based on simply having to do a lot of work

name: pc: logic challenges
description: challenge based on using logic to find correct solutions

name: pc: memory
description: challenge based on remembering vital information

name: pc: moral challenges
description: challenge based around the morality of events in the game

name: pc: other
description: any other unique challenges

name: pc: skill or dexterity
description: challenge based on mastering a skill (usally hand-eye coordination) to a certain degree

name: pc: strategy challenges
description: challenge based on problems of a strategic nature, e.g. players must manage resources and make plans to overcome challenges

name: personal challenges
description: main challenges that (we personally) feel the game gives the player

name: personalization
description: players can personalize parts of the game

name: player communication
description: which types of player-to-player communication is available

name: preset communication
description: communcation over presets, i.e., no free expression

name: problem solving
description: which problems players solve in the game and how they do it

name: randomness
description: how randomness is used inside the game (to enhance replayability)

name: reasoning
description: players must employ reasoning to tackle problems

name: rep: gameplay branches
description:
the game provides mechanics that result in different ways of playing the game (e.g. skilltree)

this does not apply to scenarios where the core gameplay is the same but with a slightly different flavor (e.g. pokemon)

name: rep: meta progression
description: players progress after finishing a game/match (e.g. increasing a character level in multiplayer games, etc.)

name: rep: narrative branches
description: players can make different choices for the narrative, resulting in different outcomes

name: rep: scoring system
description: game includes a scoring or ranking system that may motivate players to replay (sections of) the game

name: rep: unlock content
description: players unlock new content after finishing the game or a run of the game, e.g. new levels, new cosmetics, new game modes, story elements, etc.

name: repetition
description: players can tackle problems through repetition

name: replayability
description: mechanics and concepts to influence the replayability of a game

name: res: apply logic
description: players must apply logic for problem-solving, e.g., for abstract puzzles

name: res: apply physics
description: problem solving involves systems and rules based on physics, e.g. jump-and-run or more complex puzzles

name: res: combine information
description: players need to assemble pieces in the correct manner, e.g. when presenting evidence

name: res: learn or apply language
description:
merge tags:
apply preknown language, body language, learn programming, learn unknown language

name: res: process of elimination
description: problem-solving is partially based on process of elimination

name: res: social deduction
description: players need to engage in social deduction for problem-solving

name: res: strategic planning
description: players must devise an appropriate strategy to solve problems, weighing different options and uncertainty

name: resource management
description: players must manage resources to progress, e.g., items, skills, money, etc.

name: rnd: ability outcome
description: the outcome of an ability/skill is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: ability select
description: which abilities can be selected is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: agents
description: how (AI) agents are spawned or how they behave is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: enemies
description: how enemies are spawned or how they behave is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: events
description: random events can occurr during gameplay

name: rnd: loot
description: loot (items that enemies drop or that can be found in chests) is randomized to some degree, e.g., using a loot table

name: rnd: world generation
description: the game world is randomly generated to some degree, e.g., procedural generation

name: rpt: grinding
description:
players can progress by grinding, this is very similar to busywork since players continuously do the same activity, e.g. kill a specific enemy type.

can be motivated internally (players want to level-up) or because the game difficulty forces them to by not providing other means of progressing

name: rpt: practicing
description: players may want to practice to tackle a (skill) challenge or simply get better

name: rpt: trial and error
description:
players solve problems via trial and error since they can just try out different solution strategies without penalty (or with reloading)

NOTICE: only tag this when this is a viable strategy

name: sch: blueprint
description: players can define or build blueprints that function as a planning help

name: sch: copy-paste
description: players can use copy-paste features for building

name: sch: recipe
description: the game includes recipes, e.g., for crafting

name: sch: template
description: players can define (building) templates to reuse at another point in time

name: schemata
description: mechanics related to building

name: set-t: futuristic
description:
merge tags:
set-t: future, set-t: futuristic

name: set: spatial
description: which location the game takes place in or which location it heavily references

name: set: time
description: in which time period the game takes place or which time period it heavily references

name: setting
description: the setting of a game in terms of location, time and genre

name: sim: daily routines
description: agents in the game have simulated daily routines

name: sim: day-night cycle
description: the game includes a day/night cycle or meaningful connection of daytime to other game mechanics

name: sim: economy
description: the game features a simulated (even if simple) economy with supply and demand

name: sim: needs
description: the game simulates needs of people, animals, plants, etc.

name: sim: seasons & weather
description: the game simulates weather or seasons in some way meaningful to other game mechanics

name: simulation systems
description: different types of systems that games can simulate, which have an impact on other mechanics

name: spn: marker
description: the game provides markers in the game world to support spatial navigation

name: spn: object quicktravel
description: players can quicktravel using objects in the game world like portals, teleport scrolls, gates, etc.

name: spn: other
description: any other type of spatial navigation

name: spn: pings
description: players can support spatial navigation through pings (likely only multiplayer)

name: struc: cyclic
description: the game has a cyclic structure, i.e., it can (or should) be played multiple times for a good player experience

name: struc: match based
description:
the game is match-based, i.e., each play session consists of 1 or more matches that are clearly separated from each other

the most prominent examples can be found in multiplayer games (e.g. DotA 2 or Counter Strike)

name: struc: turnbased
description: (some) parts of the game are structured in a turn-based manner, usually related to combat

name: subversion: game mechanics
description: the game subverts known game mechanics

name: subversion: storytelling
description: the game subverts storytelling practices

name: top: conflict
description: topics related to conflict

name: top: culture & ethics
description: topics related to culture and questions of ethics

name: top: discrimination
description:
merge tags:
top: discrimination, top: racism, top: sexism

name: top: family & friends
description:
merge tags:
top: family, top: friendship

name: top: forms of life
description: topics related to types of life forms

name: top: other
description: for any missing topics, e.g. technology

name: top: personal struggles
description: topics related to personal struggles

name: top: supernatural
description: topics related to the supernatural

name: top: time
description: This tag marks games that have time as a central topic. For example when the needs to achieve something in a specific amount of time, or when a groundhog day scenario is at play.

name: ui personalization
description: players can personalize some parts of the UI to better match their preferences

name: ui: accessibility
description: UI settings for accessibility, e.g., a color-blind mode

name: ui: sandbox
description: UI sandbox that allows players to freely organize the layout

name: vis: bars
description: visualizations based around bars

name: vis: charts
description: any type of chart (axes + data)

name: vis: graphs
description: graph-like visualizations of data in the game

name: vis: icons & symbols
description: icons or symbols that encode game-relevant data (cannot be JUST ui elements)

name: vis: matrix & tables
description: matrix-like visualizations of data in the game

name: vis: other
description: vis collection tag

name: vis: overlay
description: data is displayed through an overlay

name: vision
description: the game models vision (player or AI agents see something) in some way

name: vision: cones
description: vision works through cones (visible)

name: vision: fog of war
description: game has fog of war, i.e., vision is limited to some area around players and other items/units/objects that give vision

name: vision: other
description: game includes some other form of vision model

name: what you do
description: what players mostly "do" while playing, what the main activities are

name: wyd: detective work
description: e.g. whodunit

name: ai companions
description:
the game includes AI companions that accompany the player (if there is a player character) for some time

NOTICE: does not include escort missions

name: ai: commandable
description: AI companions can be commanded (fully or partially)

name: ai: uncommandable
description: AI companions cannot be commanded

name: auto: assemble
description:
automation is directly build/assembled, usually some kind of machine

something can only count as automation if it could also be done manually by the player in some other way, with the automation therefore replacing manual labor (preferably introducing a certain depth)

name: auto: configure
description:
automation is configured but not directly build/assembled

something can only count as automation if it could also be done manually by the player in some other way, with the automation therefore replacing manual labor (preferably introducing a certain depth)

name: automation
description: automating processes via game mechanics is helpful or mandatory for problem solving

name: character editor
description: the game has a character editor which allows the player to personalize the character they play to some degree (age, gender, name, class, race, ..)

name: chunk: continuous
description: no clear boundaries, seamless transitions between different game parts

name: chunk: package wise
description: clear boundaries, different game parts can be named (or even separately chosen to play again)

name: chunkiness
description: how game contents are packaged, i.e. are there no clear boundaries between different game parts (open world) or are there clear separations (levels)

name: com: chat wheel
description:
players can post premade messages to a chat, usually by using a wheel where they can choose between a set of available messages

This acts as a barrier for toxicity and does not require devs to implement chat filters.

name: com: external
description: players communicate outside of the game, e.g. because they are in the same location or by using other software

name: com: free drawing
description: players can draw to communicate with other players, e.g. by drawing on a map to indicate where something is

name: com: free gestures
description: players can communicate via free gestures (most likely only VR games)

name: com: gestures
description: players can communicate using a set of predefined gestures their character can make

name: com: markers and pings
description: players can communicate through markers and pings, i.e., small symbolic representations

name: com: npc and npc
description: NPCs talk to each other (e.g. ambient dialog or cutscenes) which can act as a source of information for the player

name: com: npc and player
description: NPCs communicate with the player (not their in-game character), e.g. in a tutorial. This can include narrators.

name: com: npc and playercharacter
description: players can communicate with NPCs via their in-game character, e.g. to gather information, complete quests, trade resources or just chat

name: com: proximity communication
description:
Communication is bound to a location, e.g. players can only hear each other when they are close to each other in the game world.
This is allowed to be tagged for single player games.

name: com: soundboard
description: players can communicate through a sound board, e.g., through a set of predefined spoken lines (voiced by someone else)

name: com: text chat
description: players can communicate through a text chat

name: com: voice chat
description: players can communicate through a voice chat

name: communication
description: how communication is handled in the game

name: content & substance
description: the general content and substance of a game in terms of topics and setting

name: dd: arrow indicator
description: players are shown a direction through an arrow indicator

name: dd: compass
description: players can understand directions through a compass

name: dd: ingame path trail
description: directions are given through a path that is overlayed on the game world, e.g. to show players which way they must go

name: direction display
description: the game provides directional displays for spatial guidance

name: enact violence
description: players solve problems or progress by enacting violence like killing creatures and defeating enemies

name: exp: heterogeneous
description: players get a diverse game experience

name: exp: homogeneous
description: players get a more homogeneous game experience

name: form
description: the form of a game, including its mechanics and structure

name: free communication
description: communcation with some degree of free expression

name: game experience
description: how diverse the game experience is, i.e., are there many different aspects and activities to it or is it largely the same

name: game object personalization
description: players can personalize game objects, e.g., through naming, coloring or cosmetics (clothing, hair styles)

name: game over condition
description: how/when the game is over

name: gather information
description: players must identify and gather information themselves to progress, e.g. by inspecting objects or talking to NPCs

name: genre
description: which genre from other media (film, literature) the game can be assigned to

name: ginfo: dialog
description: players collect information by talking to NPCs

name: ginfo: exploration
description: players gather information by investigating their environment in the hopes of finding something, e.g. new items, an NPCs to talk to, etc.

name: ginfo: lookup
description:
players gather information by looking up information in the game (looking at letters, looking at the quest log)

NOTICE: this does not include *searching*

name: ginfo: remember self
description: players must take care to remember gathered information themselves, since the game does not track it

name: ginfo: scouting
description: players collect information by (repeadetly) investigating an area, e.g. to check that nothing is there or to get information on an enemy

name: ginfo: text search
description: players can search through information by specifying search terms

name: goc: critical failure
description: game is over when the player fails critically, e.g., death, resets to a previous point in the game, thereby losing any progress between this point and the critical failure

name: goc: none
description: there is no direct game over condition, e.g., because the game continues after the story ends (Minecraft) or because there was no end to begin with (endless mode)

name: goc: permadeath
description: when the player dies, the game resets to the start

name: goc: reach endpoint
description: the game ends when a certain point is reached, e.g., the conclusion of the main quest

name: info: arrange
description: players can spatially arrange information

name: info: connect
description: players can (visually) connect pieces of information, e.g. via red strings like a graph

name: info: distribute
description: players must distribute information amongst themselves to tackle problems (multiplayer only)

name: info: mark/tag
description: players can tag information, which can be abstract or concrete, e.g. by tagging video clips based on their content

name: info: other
description: placeholder for any missing tags to organize information

name: info: record
description: players can record information themselves, e.g. with a text note

name: info: visibility
description:
players can (visually) hide information not relevant to the current problem, e.g. by clicking an item to reduce its rendering opacity

this does not include being able to show or hide information in windows, e.g. a quest log

name: information
description: players must organize resources to succeed (e.g min-maxing)

name: int: highlight
description: visual highlights, e.g. for status changes, important entities, etc.

name: int: new data
description: the game communicates that new data is available to the player, e.g., a new quest, new log entry, new armor, etc.

name: int: visual aid
description: the game has visual aids (mostly for navigation) like ledges that are painted in a particular color to indicate that they can be climbed on

name: leave behind artifacts
description: players can leave behind artifacts in a shared game world

name: map: drawing
description: players can draw on a map

name: map: minimap
description: the game includes a minimap version of a larger map

name: map: path trail
description: path trails are shown on a map

name: map: place symbols
description: players can place symbols on the map, e.g. location markers

name: map: quicktravel
description:
players can use a map to quickly travel to other locations

NOTICE: A game feature is only quicktravel if the player could also travel the same distance in a slower way e.g. walking by foot vs clicking on the minimap.

name: map: symbols
description: the game includes a map (at all), usually with symbols that provide information on specific locations

name: mech: card game
description: Has mechanics based around card games. This can be actual card games or just prominent elements of card games.

name: mech: challenges
description: (optional) content intended to challenge players' skill

name: mech: change game speed
description: players can change the speed of the game, e.g., through slow motion/bullet time, by having a tactical pause or directly controling the speed (slower/faster)

name: mech: combos
description: the game has combos in some sense, e.g., when players successfully chain or combine (specific) attacks, when players can craft combos, etc.

name: mech: configurable quick access
description: player can configure some type of quick access

name: mech: other
description: for any missing tags related to mechanics

name: mech: physical save points
description:
there are physical objects in the game where the player can save and/or rest, optionally with replenishing their health

saving can mean creating a new save file or getting a new check point

name: mech: place & arrange
description: players can place and arrange objects inside the game world, usually employed for building

name: mech: predefined notes
description: the game provides information in the form of notes, audio diaries, encylopedias, letters, etc.

name: mech: quest tracker display
description: players can see their current quest objectives/tasks displayed on the screen (automatically or by setting a quest as active)

name: mech: queue
description: players can queue specific actions like movement or more complex commands; does not count if the game only internally uses a queue

name: mech: quicktime events
description: events that require players to press a specific button in a given amount of time; can have bad consequences if failed

name: mech: skilltree & upgrades
description: game includes a systems, like a skill or research tree, where upgrades are successively unlocked

name: mech: stealth
description: the game has stealth mechanics like sneaking, wearing disguises or stealing

name: mech: transform
description: players can transform things inside the game into other things, e.g. crafting

name: mech: vehicles & mounts
description:
players can use vehicles or mounts (e.g., horses, dragons, etc.) to traverse the world
- have their own controls
- alternative way of moving

name: mechanics
description: A mechanic is a feature that the game provides such that the player is able to accomplish game given tasks. This is not the same as what you do.

name: meta-mechanics
description: high-level features of a game

name: mini: busywork
description: minigames that consist of busywork (see "busywork" tag), e.g. trivial and repetitive tasks

name: mini: logic
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved by employing logic, e.g Towers of Hanoi

name: mini: skill
description: includes minigames that can primarily be solved through skill, e.g clicking objects in a short time frame in the correct order

name: minigames
description: mini-games that reward players with progress in some form

name: misc
description: miscellaneous

name: misc: collectibles
description: the game has collectible items that players can collect during gameplay and that are usually displayed in a gallery somewhere

name: misc: community content
description: the game allows for community content (e.g., via the steam workshop)

name: misc: difficulty settings
description: the game allows players to customize the difficulty by selecting a difficulty level or customized game settings that influence difficulty

name: misc: educational
description:
the game includes educational content that directly aims to be educational

NOTICE: This does not include when information/architecture is based on the real-world but just part of the game as such. There must be obvious intent to educate.

name: misc: secrets
description: the game includes content that is hidden or not easily accessible, e.g. easter eggs, treasures, special endings ..

name: misc: tutorial
description: the game includes a tutorial of some kind (can be big or small)

name: mng: compose team
description:
players need to compose a team of units

requires that units influence each other e.g. in terms of interaction

name: mng: consumables
description: players need to manage consumable resources like money, materials, potions, etc.

name: mng: inventory
description: players need to manage their inventory , which is limited by space or weight (choose which items to keep)

name: mng: items
description: players need to manage which items they use, buy, equip, etc.

name: mng: skills
description: players need to manage skills, e.g., when to use a skill, when to upgrade it or which skills to equip

name: mng: time
description: players need to manage time, e.g., because the game has other systems based around time

name: mng: units
description: players need to manage mutliple units

name: mul: couch coop
description: cooperative multiplayer that is played in the same location, using a single device

name: mul: leave game objects
description: players can leave behind objects in the shared world

name: mul: leave text
description: players can add (persistent) text to the game world

name: mul: local multiplayer
description: multiplayer that is played in the same network (LAN), using multiple devices

name: mul: online multiplayer
description: multiplayer that is played online (using multiple devices)

name: multiplayer
description: multiplayer mechanics and categories

name: npc communication
description: which type of communication with NPCs is available

name: ord: branches
description: game contents can be experienced/accessed in a branched order, i.e., there are different options but still some restrictions

name: ord: linear
description: game contents can only be experienced/accessed in a predetermined linear order

name: ord: open
description: game contents can be experienced/accessed in any order, e.g., in open-world games

name: order
description: describes in which order game contents can be experienced/accessed

name: organize information
description: players can organize information to progress (or make their lives easier)

name: pc: discovery
description: challenge based on discovery of new information about the story, game world, characters, etc.

name: pc: emotional challenges
description: challenge based on emotional reactions to story developments or other parts of the game

name: pc: labor or busywork
description: challenge based on simply having to do a lot of work

name: pc: logic challenges
description: challenge based on using logic to find correct solutions

name: pc: memory
description: challenge based on remembering vital information

name: pc: moral challenges
description: challenge based around the morality of events in the game

name: pc: other
description: any other unique challenges

name: pc: skill or dexterity
description: challenge based on mastering a skill (usally hand-eye coordination) to a certain degree

name: pc: strategy challenges
description: challenge based on problems of a strategic nature, e.g. players must manage resources and make plans to overcome challenges

description: main challenges that (we personally) feel the game gives the player

name: personalization
description: players can personalize parts of the game

name: player communication
description: which types of player-to-player communication is available

name: preset communication
description: communcation over presets, i.e., no free expression

name: problem solving
description: which problems players solve in the game and how they do it

name: randomness
description: how randomness is used inside the game (to enhance replayability)

name: reasoning
description: players must employ reasoning to tackle problems

name: rep: gameplay branches
description:
the game provides mechanics that result in different ways of playing the game (e.g. skilltree)

this does not apply to scenarios where the core gameplay is the same but with a slightly different flavor (e.g. pokemon)

name: rep: meta progression
description: players progress after finishing a game/match (e.g. increasing a character level in multiplayer games, etc.)

name: rep: narrative branches
description: players can make different choices for the narrative, resulting in different outcomes

name: rep: scoring system
description: game includes a scoring or ranking system that may motivate players to replay (sections of) the game

name: rep: unlock content
description: players unlock new content after finishing the game or a run of the game, e.g. new levels, new cosmetics, new game modes, story elements, etc.

name: repetition
description: players can tackle problems through repetition

name: replayability
description: mechanics and concepts to influence the replayability of a game

name: res: apply logic
description: players must apply logic for problem-solving, e.g., for abstract puzzles

name: res: apply physics
description: problem solving involves systems and rules based on physics, e.g. jump-and-run or more complex puzzles

name: res: combine information
description: players need to assemble pieces in the correct manner, e.g. when presenting evidence

name: res: learn or apply language
description:
merge tags:
apply preknown language, body language, learn programming, learn unknown language

name: res: process of elimination
description: problem-solving is partially based on process of elimination

name: res: social deduction
description: players need to engage in social deduction for problem-solving

name: res: strategic planning
description: players must devise an appropriate strategy to solve problems, weighing different options and uncertainty

name: resource management
description: players must manage resources to progress, e.g., items, skills, money, etc.

name: rnd: ability outcome
description: the outcome of an ability/skill is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: ability select
description: which abilities can be selected is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: agents
description: how (AI) agents are spawned or how they behave is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: enemies
description: how enemies are spawned or how they behave is randomized to some degree

name: rnd: events
description: random events can occurr during gameplay

name: rnd: loot
description: loot (items that enemies drop or that can be found in chests) is randomized to some degree, e.g., using a loot table

name: rnd: world generation
description: the game world is randomly generated to some degree, e.g., procedural generation

name: rpt: grinding
description:
players can progress by grinding, this is very similar to busywork since players continuously do the same activity, e.g. kill a specific enemy type.

can be motivated internally (players want to level-up) or because the game difficulty forces them to by not providing other means of progressing

name: rpt: practicing
description: players may want to practice to tackle a (skill) challenge or simply get better

name: rpt: trial and error
description:
players solve problems via trial and error since they can just try out different solution strategies without penalty (or with reloading)

NOTICE: only tag this when this is a viable strategy

name: sch: blueprint
description: players can define or build blueprints that function as a planning help

name: sch: copy-paste
description: players can use copy-paste features for building

name: sch: recipe
description: the game includes recipes, e.g., for crafting

name: sch: template
description: players can define (building) templates to reuse at another point in time

name: schemata
description: mechanics related to building

name: set-t: futuristic
description:
merge tags:
set-t: future, set-t: futuristic

name: set: spatial
description: which location the game takes place in or which location it heavily references

name: set: time
description: in which time period the game takes place or which time period it heavily references

name: setting
description: the setting of a game in terms of location, time and genre

name: sim: daily routines
description: agents in the game have simulated daily routines

name: sim: day-night cycle
description: the game includes a day/night cycle or meaningful connection of daytime to other game mechanics

name: sim: economy
description: the game features a simulated (even if simple) economy with supply and demand

name: sim: needs
description: the game simulates needs of people, animals, plants, etc.

name: sim: seasons & weather
description: the game simulates weather or seasons in some way meaningful to other game mechanics

name: simulation systems
description: different types of systems that games can simulate, which have an impact on other mechanics

name: spn: marker
description: the game provides markers in the game world to support spatial navigation

name: spn: object quicktravel
description: players can quicktravel using objects in the game world like portals, teleport scrolls, gates, etc.

name: spn: other
description: any other type of spatial navigation

name: spn: pings
description: players can support spatial navigation through pings (likely only multiplayer)

name: struc: cyclic
description: the game has a cyclic structure, i.e., it can (or should) be played multiple times for a good player experience

name: struc: match based
description:
the game is match-based, i.e., each play session consists of 1 or more matches that are clearly separated from each other

the most prominent examples can be found in multiplayer games (e.g. DotA 2 or Counter Strike)

name: struc: turnbased
description: (some) parts of the game are structured in a turn-based manner, usually related to combat

name: subversion: game mechanics
description: the game subverts known game mechanics

name: subversion: storytelling
description: the game subverts storytelling practices

name: top: conflict
description: topics related to conflict

name: top: culture & ethics
description: topics related to culture and questions of ethics

name: top: discrimination
description:
merge tags:
top: discrimination, top: racism, top: sexism

name: top: family & friends
description:
merge tags:
top: family, top: friendship

name: top: forms of life
description: topics related to types of life forms

name: top: other
description: for any missing topics, e.g. technology

name: top: personal struggles
description: topics related to personal struggles

name: top: supernatural
description: topics related to the supernatural

name: top: time
description: This tag marks games that have time as a central topic. For example when the needs to achieve something in a specific amount of time, or when a groundhog day scenario is at play.

name: ui personalization
description: players can personalize some parts of the UI to better match their preferences

name: ui: accessibility
description: UI settings for accessibility, e.g., a color-blind mode

name: ui: sandbox
description: UI sandbox that allows players to freely organize the layout

name: vis: bars
description: visualizations based around bars

name: vis: charts
description: any type of chart (axes + data)

name: vis: graphs
description: graph-like visualizations of data in the game

name: vis: icons & symbols
description: icons or symbols that encode game-relevant data (cannot be JUST ui elements)

name: vis: matrix & tables
description: matrix-like visualizations of data in the game

name: vis: other
description: vis collection tag

name: vis: overlay
description: data is displayed through an overlay

name: vision
description: the game models vision (player or AI agents see something) in some way

name: vision: cones
description: vision works through cones (visible)

name: vision: fog of war
description: game has fog of war, i.e., vision is limited to some area around players and other items/units/objects that give vision

name: vision: other
description: game includes some other form of vision model

name: what you do
description: what players mostly "do" while playing, what the main activities are

name: wyd: detective work
description: e.g. whodunit

name: accusationcomplex
description: Selection via complex player input.

name: accusationsimple
description: Selection per predefined dialog

name: action queue
description: players can add actions to a queue which persists their intentions

name: automation
description: Automating processes via game mechanics is helpful or mandatory for problem solving

name: blueprint
description: players can define or build blueprints that are used for planning

name: busywork
description: players must simply do work in order to progress, but the work does not require problem solving as such

name: chat wheel
description: players can post premade messages to a chat

name: choose dialog option
description: players often progress by choosing an (appropriate) dialog option

name: communication
description: players must communicate to coordinate their game actions or solve problems

name: contradiction
description: players must find contradictions

name: copypaste
description: predefined, self created, global, lokal, clipboard

name: customization
description: players can customize objects in the game, e.g. by renaming, coloring or more

name: deduction
description: players need to apply deduction for problem solving

name: devise strategy
description: players must devise an appropriate strategy to solve problems

name: gather information
description: players must identify and gather information themselves, e.g. by inspecting objects or talking to NPCs

name: hide information
description: players can (visually) hide things not relevant to the current problem

name: highlight information
description: players can choose to highlight specific information, e.g. that they deem relevant

name: induction
description: players must use inductive reasoning to solve problems

name: inputbuffer
description: Input is persistent even if it can not be executed immediately.

name: language
description: language is a central topic for problem solving

name: location display
description: players can see markers or symbols that provide information

name: location guidance
description: players are automatically guided to a location, e.g. via markers or a trail

name: location markers
description: players can add location markers (e.g. to a map)

name: map drawing
description: players can draw on a map

name: minigames
description: includes mini-games that reward players with progress in some form

name: notes
description: players can create their own text notes

name: nothing
description: nooooothing

name: organization
description: players must organize resources to succeed (e.g min-maxing)

name: pew pew
description: players must overcome enemies with violence to progress

name: physics
description: problem solving involves systems and rules based on physics, e.g. jump-and-run or more complex puzzles

name: point and click
description: the game belongs to the point-and-click genre, i.e. players must solve riddles by talking to NPCs, combining and using items

name: possibilities
description: players can define which possibilities they think are relevant

name: possibilities (pseudo)
description: players may think he has different possibilities for something

name: predefined notes
description: includes some form of tagging system

name: pseudo blueprint
description: Players can define areas where something should happen

name: puzzle pieces
description: players need to assemble pieces in the correct manner, e.g. when presenting evidence

name: queuegame
description: e.g. Dorfromantik

name: randomness
description: players face challenges that include random components, e.g. random maps, tools, cards or enemies

name: red strings
description: connect evidence pieces via red strings like a graph

name: reusable blueprints
description: players can define blueprints or template to reuse at another point in time

name: riddles
description: players must solve riddles to progress

name: rules
description: players must apply game rules correctly

name: secrets
description: Game content that is hidden or not easily accessible (e.g. easter eggs, treasures, endings ...)

name: social deduction
description: players need to engage in social deduction

name: strategy (optional)
description: players can devise an appropriate strategy to solve problems

name: tagging
description: includes some form of tagging system

name: template
description: players can define blueprints or template to reuse at another point in time

name: text in world
description: players can add (persistent) text to the game world

name: text search
description: players can search through information by specifying search terms

name: trial and error
description: players solve problems via trial and error since they can just try out different solution strategies without penalty (or with reloading)
